title: My husband has stopped paying his credit cards bills. Our bills are not combined, will or can this effect me?
question: I'm wondering if I need to protect myself, he is very careless. I'm currently a fulltime student, with loans soon to set in. Wondering about a legal separation so that his bills do not become mine. Any suggestions?
question_tags: Divorce,Alternatives to divorce,Legal separation and divorce,Dividing debts in a divorce,Community property in divorce,Child support,Divorce and bankruptcy,Bankruptcy,Credit,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Real estate and bankruptcy,Real estate,Spousal debt,Marriage
answers: Although if you are not listed as a co-debtor on the account(s) you could not be sued personally, that does not mean that creditor could not take community property to satisfy a judgment against your husband. Moreover, it may affect your ability to obtain credit in the future. Moreover, it also doesn't mean you won't have to deal with the phone calls from collection agencies.

When the creditors sue your husband to collect these debts, any bank accounts, real estate, motor vehicles, or other property you own jointly could be vulnerable to being seized once a court judgment is entered.

Trust your instincts & be careful. A man that doesn't pay his credit cards won't pay child support either.

I do not practice in California, however, if your name is not tied to the bill, the creditor should NOT be able to attach you, simply because you are married.
